msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This manuscript is a humanist copy of the first book of Jacques de Vitry's thirteenth-century history, on Jerusalem or the Orient. The manuscript is written in one hundred chapters whose titles are listed in a table of contents at the beginning of the volume. The colophon at the end of the table of contents (fol. 5r) records that Johannes de Camenago copied the manuscript in 1459 in Milan. At least one leaf of the preface (before fol. 6) is missing, perhaps taken for its decoration. Occasional corrections and notes appear in the margins.

msItem.title: Historia hierosolymitana (History of Jerusalem)
msItem.author: Jacques, de Vitry, approximately 1170-1240
msItem.colophon: Scriptum opus p[raese]ns fuit per me Johannem de Camenago M[edio]l[an]en[sem] 1459 (fol. 5r)

msItem.title: Historia Hierosolymitana
msItem.explicit: â€¦ et subsidium de die in diem expectantes. Laus altissimo deo. [fol. 140v]

supportDesc.extent: i+139+i; 213 x 152 mm bound to 220 x 165 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto

p.catchwords: Vertical catchwords by the scribe in quires 3-18, lower right last verso

layoutDesc.layout: One column of twenty-eight lines, ruled in hard point and lead with double vertical bounding lines; lacking first leaf of text (between extant fols. 5 and 6); written area: 122 x 75 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: Three-line initials in red with purple flourishes or blue with red flourishes at the beginning of each chapter; rubrication in red
Inside front coverBookplate, Count Archinto of Milan

binding.p: Eighteenth-century green vellum; gilt spine; spine label "HISTORIA IEROSOLIMITANA"; edges sprinkled with red; joints cracked, front joint almost completely broken

history.provenance: Count Archinto, of Milan (bookplate with "Archineata" on the scroll at the top, "Count Archinti" in pencil below, inside front cover); Thomas Phillipps, MS 24276 (number in ink, fol. 1r); John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936
